fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Case 1: f is a constant polynomial. Then |f| attains its minimum value at every point in \mathbb {C}, so pick z_{0}=0 and we're done.

Case 2: f is not a constant polynomial. Then we can write it out as f(z)=a_{n}z^{n}+…+a_{1}z+a_{0} where n=\deg (f) is the degree of f, with a_{n}\neq 0. Set A=\max \{|a_{0}|,…,|a_{n}|\} Then we have A/|a_{n}|\geq 1, so |f(z)|\geq |a_{n}||z|^{n}\left (1-\frac {A}{|a_{n}|}\sum ^{\infty }_{k=1}\frac {1}{|z|^{k}}\right )=|a_{n}||z|^{n}\left (1-\frac {A}{|a_{n}|}\frac {1}{|z|-1}\right ) For all z\in \mathbb {C} such that |z|\geq 2, we can simplify this lower bound as |f(z)|\geq |a_{n}||z|^{n}\left (1-\frac {2A}{|a_{n}||z|}\right ) This implies there exists an R>0 such that |f(z)|>|f(0)| for all z\in \mathbb {C} such that |z|>R. Let D\subseteq \mathbb {R}^{2} be the close disk of radius R centered at the origin, then define g\colon D\to \mathbb {R} by g(x,y)=|f(x+\mathrm {i} y)|. Since g is continuous, we apply Extreme value theorem to obtain a point (x_{0},y_{0})\in D such that g attains a minimum at (x_{0},y_{0}). By the choice of R we have that for z\in \mathbb {C}\setminus D, |f(z)|>|g(0,0)|\geq |g(x_{0},y_{0})|. Therefore |f| attains its minimum at z=x_{0}+\mathrm {i} y_{0}.
